text:
Hi everyone! I hope you’re all well! 

Did anyone have in-person events/conferences planned for this season that had to be moved online? If so, what was it like making that shift? Was the virtual version of the event successful? 

Thanks!

text:
My former job moved everything to online and it has been wonderful to see how they’ve adapted.

FirstRoundReview has a really great read on this: <https://firstround.com/review/dont-just-throw-together-a-webinar-the-virtual-events-crash-course-you-need/>

My friends at CreativeMornings wrote a beautiful, thoughtful guide on hosting virtual gatherings: <https://docs.google.com/document/d/1KLRrnm6g5YvD8QRSPwwNWq6NPk9FYvMpZPy_XEyOmMM/edit?fbclid=IwAR2OjRshegmClOrWi7ZuUjARGbd2AwzRzSX5S-7aEywPznUC_d7lvfc07hU>

attachments.text: Teresa Zimmerman serves as the Vice President of Marketing at Personify and Erin Geoffroy develops and executes marketing campaigns across Personify’s verticals and suite of products and leads brand marketing initiatives.

attachments.text: It can take a lot of work, communication, planning, and forethought to take a conference or show into the virtual space.
attachments.fallback: Personify Corp: Planning and Executing an Engaging Virtual Event, with Teresa Zimmerman, Erin Geoffroy, and Julia Thurston | Personify Corp

attachments.title: Choosing the Right Content for Your Virtual Event, with Teresa Zimmerman, Erin Geoffroy, and Megan Lopez | Personify Corp
attachments.text: When you are taking a real-world event into the virtual space, it is important to consider your attendees’ experience and determine what content best fits the digital platform.
attachments.fallback: Personify Corp: Choosing the Right Content for Your Virtual Event, with Teresa Zimmerman, Erin Geoffroy, and Megan Lopez | Personify Corp

attachments.text: On this episode of Planet Leadership, Teresa Zimmerman, Erin Geoffroy and Kevin Gough from the Personifest event team discuss tips and strategies for meeting the needs of a virtual event’s sponsors.

text:
Quick question for all those new to working from home: what’s your biggest remote working trouble/challenge? Particularly, related to working with your team? 

P.S. if there any team managers here, I’d love to chat with you on this. :)

elements.text: Quick question for all those new to working from home: what’s your biggest remote working trouble/challenge? Particularly, related to working with your team?
P.S. if there any team managers here, I’d love to chat with you on this. :)
Hi
, thanks for sharing!

text:
I'm not new to remote working, but having worked in both fully-remote and 'flexible' work environments, the biggest challenge is always communication.

Teams who are used to having a free flowing exchange of information in person seem to have a difficult time communicating online. People might feel like they're missing out on important information. They might miss being able to just drop in on conversations that are happening around them. And managers might feel anxious that they can't monitor productivity when they're not able to see people working at their desks.

All of this can lead to too little communication (people not knowing what's going on, duplicating work, etc) or too much communication (managers filling peoples' calendars with unnecessary calls to constantly 'check in').

elements.text:

Teams who are used to having a free flowing exchange of information in person seem to have a difficult time communicating online. People might feel like they're missing out on important information. They might miss being able to just drop in on conversations that are happening around them. And managers might feel anxious that they can't monitor productivity when they're not able to see people working at their desks.

All of this can lead to too little communication (people not knowing what's going on, duplicating work, etc) or too much communication (managers filling peoples' calendars with unnecessary calls to constantly 'check in').

text: That’s a good point, Anton. Thanks for taking out the time to share it with me. I was just talking about the same with another person. Since you mentioned you aren’t new to remote working, how do think managers can best tackle this communication gap?

text: Much of our team (myself included) has been working remote prior to COVID-19, but my direct team (and many of my day-to-day teammates) have suddenly become remote full-time. Previously, they have always had the opportunity to work remote when they chose, but would get together in the office weekly for the comaraderie. That’s now gone, and that has been a tougher transition, especially for those that live alone. To combat that, we’re doing regular virtual breakfasts (for the international teams), virtual lunch, and even virtual happy hour. It’s certainly helped combat the lack of in-house banter. Nothing much has changed with our communication style, other than we overcommunicate now more than ever (e.g. I often have to step away to deal with kids during the day, and I didn’t have that previously because they were at school). I certainly wouldn’t consider that latter part a trouble or challenge - it’s actually made everyone more human and understanding that each of our circumstances is different.

text: Hi, everyone. Since layoffs are so common with all the current events, I'm curious what other companies are doing to increase both team and individual morale for the employees they retain. Any experiences/ideas anyone can to share?

elements.text: Hi, everyone. Since layoffs are so common with all the current events, I'm curious what other companies are doing to increase both team and individual morale for the employees they retain. Any experiences/ideas anyone can to share?

text:
I set up a 30-minute morning coffee chat that’s open for anyone to join. We run it from 9:45-10:15.

It’s been super nice to connect with everyone in the morning, joke around and then really dive into work

elements.text:
I set up a 30-minute morning coffee chat that’s open for anyone to join. We run it from 9:45-10:15.

It’s been super nice to connect with everyone in the morning, joke around and then really dive into work

text:
I've been really appreciative of my company culture during the pandemic! Here are a few things that we're doing:
• My team does an AM and PM pomodoro style call open for anyone to join. 30 minute periods where we tell each other what we're working on, work with our mics left on (simulate office sounds), then report our progress at the end. Keeps you accountable and focused while having some company
• The Toronto office also has a weekly zoom lunch as does my individual team 
• We also have weekly optional events you can join after work such as a games night, baking class, lunch time yoga session, a number of us are taking the McGill Personal Finance course so we run through modules together at lunch, etc
• Created a channel to share activities/music + movie recommendations/etc to do while in quarantine
• Optional company wide fitness challenge with daily check-ins and prizes as incentives
• Fistbumps channel to give shoutouts in (had this before covid, but even more active now that we're remote)
Lots of small initiatives, but makes me feel really connected to the team and keeps our spirits up!

text: Our leadership team has started organizing weekly “fireside chat” style Zoom calls with customers so we all stay super connected to the company’s mission and the problems we’re solving for our customers.
